title: 108_hr5164
content: The "National Health Museum Act of 2004" establishes a site for the construction and operation of a national health museum. The Act defines key terms such as Administrator, CERCLA, Committees, Museum, and northern portion of the property. The property, located in the District of Columbia, consists of Squares 325 and 326, and parts of Squares 351 and 352, including the "Cotton Annex". It is bounded by 12th Street, Independence Avenue, Maryland Avenue, the James Forrestal Building, and L'Enfant Plaza. The southern portion of the property refers to the portion deemed appropriate for the museum facility by the Administrator and Museum. The "southern portion of the property" refers to the part of the property designated for the museum facility, excluding the northern portion. The text chunk "SEC. 4. CONVEYANCE OF PROPERTY" refers to the transfer of property ownership. The Administrator has the authority to convey the property to the Museum on terms that protect US interests and further the Act's purposes. An agreement must be made within 60 days, addressing mitigation of impacts, security, and operational protocols. The property may be conveyed separately as northern and southern portions. The Administrator will convey the property to the Museum in separate northern and southern portions. The purchase price will be based on fair market value determined by an independent appraisal mutually agreed upon by both parties. The appraisal terms and conditions for the property conveyance to the Museum include assumptions about hazardous substances and separate values for the northern and southern portions. The property will be conveyed in two quit claim deeds for the northern and southern portions, with the purchase price paid into the Federal Buildings Fund. The Administrator can use the proceeds for any lawful purpose but must notify the Committees 30 days in advance of any expenditure. The property will be conveyed in two quit claim deeds for the northern and southern portions. The southern portion will contain covenants required by CERCLA. The United States will not be liable for additional remedial action unless caused by them. The northern portion will be dedicated for a national health museum. The northern portion of the property will be dedicated for use as a site for a national health museum for a 99-year period. If the portion is not used for the museum or construction does not begin within 5 years, it will revert to the United States without repayment. The Administrator has the authority to enforce reversionary rights and take custody of property if it reverts to the United States. The Administrator must convey the northern and southern portions of the property within 3 years, with the option to extend the deadline if needed for the Museum's obligations. The requirements of the Act will remain in effect. The Act will remain in force for any property conveyed before the deadline set by paragraph (1) or any extensions granted. SEC. 5. OFFICE LEASE. Negotiation and Execution: The Administrator and the Museum must negotiate and execute a lease agreement within 60 days. The lease will involve approximately 250,000 square feet in a building to be constructed by the Museum. The lease must be finalized before the conveyance of the property. The rent charged to the Administrator will be below prevailing market rates. The Administrator and the Museum must negotiate and execute a lease agreement within 60 days for approximately 250,000 square feet in a building to be constructed by the Museum. The rent charged will be below prevailing market rates, and the Administrator may apply proceeds from property conveyance towards rental charges. The lease terms must allow scoring as an operating lease according to Office guidance. The lease under this section is a precondition to conveyance of the property to the Museum. SEC. 6. ENVIRONMENTAL MATTERS. The Museum will conduct and bear costs of environmental remediation activities for the property. Remediation costs will be credited to the purchase price. Scope of activities will comply with CERCLA. SEC. 7. INCIDENTAL COSTS. SEC. 7. INCIDENTAL COSTS. The Museum is responsible for all costs related to complying with the Act, including studies, surveys, relocating tenants, and mitigating impacts on Federal buildings. The Museum will pay for relocating tenants up to an agreed amount with the Administrator. Any excess costs will be credited towards the property purchase price. Existing Authorities: This Act does not limit the authority of the National Capital Planning Commission or the Commission of Fine Arts. The Administrator must cooperate with the Museum on zoning and land use matters related to property development. Cooperation is subject to limitations, and the Administrator is not required to incur any costs. Consent for zoning and permitting is contingent on the property being developed in accordance with the Act. The Museum must submit annual reports to the Administrator and Committees detailing development and construction activities as required by this Act, within one year of enactment and annually thereafter until the end of the 5-year period following property conveyance or museum facility completion.
